tags.description:
**Organizations** are a key concept in Elorus. Each user is assigned a role 
within an organization / company, depending on which he may or may not 
be able to perform actions. To specify the organization on which you 
wish to operate, you must provide the custom 
`X-Elorus-Organization` HTTP header:

    X-Elorus-Organization: 128759403567807

Since each API key represents a user, the ability to retrieve, update or 
delete data **depends on the user role** within the specified organization.

In the event of an unauthorized request, the Elorus API returns a `HTTP 403` 
response. Additional details about the error may be provided within the 
response body.

The use of `X-Elorus-Organization` is explicitly documented where needed,
under the *Header Parameters* section. 

To start developing with the Elorus API you need to sign up for a free account.
The best way to try out Elorus and test your code is through 
[demo organizations](#tag/Using-the-API).
tags.name: Authorization

tags.description:
## Demo organizations

While developing your application, 
it is recommended to restrict all API requests only to demo organizations 
by providing the `X-Elorus-Demo` HTTP header:

    X-Elorus-Demo: true


This way Elorus will enforce a demo organization, preventing accidental data 
loss on production organizations. Demo organizations are a special form of 
organizations, suitable for reviewing 
Elorus and experimenting with the API. Within a demo organization:

- You can create unlimited documents to unlimited clients / suppliers.
- You can only have a single user - yourself.
- User management & plan subscription functionality is disabled both in 
the application UI and the API.
- Data is automatically reset at the 1st of every month.

****
Currently demo organizations are created only upon request. Contact the [Elorus 
support team](mailto:support@elorus.com) to get started with your demo 
organization.
****

## Call rate limits

Each user has a hard limit of 1000 API calls per day. 
At the same time, a user may not perform more than 60 requests 
per minute. If an API call e these limits, you will receive an 
`HTTP 429` response. The accompanying error message will look like 
`"Request was throttled. Expected available in 60.0 seconds"`.

## Localization

### Language

The English language is used throughout the Elorus API, regardless 
of the authenticated user's language preference. The English
locale conventions are also used for decimal numbers and dates:

- The character `.` is used as a floating point for decimal numbers.
- Dates are expected & returned in the form of `YYYY-mm-dd`.

### Timezone
The UTC timezone is used throughout the Elorus API. 
Datetime values are formatted in the standard ISO format.
tags.name: Using the API

tags.description: A contact may be a client, supplier or both.
tags.name: contacts

tags.description:
An invoice holds information regarding the actual transaction
(such as the client, date, amounts etc.), as well as additional
information needed to render the document as PDF.

#### PDF rendering
The entity responsible for rendering invoices to PDF is called
[Template](#tag/themes). Templates dictate the design (such as
the layout, color schemes, logo etc) as well as the contents
of the PDF (language, show / hide payment details etc.).

Invoices may override certain template
settings, to allow for a full control over the PDF rendering of a 
particular invoice. These settings are found under the `template_settings`
group of fields.

#### Client data
Invoices also keep a copy of all the client information that will
appear on the PDF. As a result you may modify the underlying client
[contact](#tag/contacts) (e.g. update the billing address) 
without affecting the printable form of past transactions with that client.


#### Payment gateways
If you want to let clients pay online, you must associate 
one or more [payment gateways](#tag/paymentgateways) with your invoices.
Each invoice may have a distinct set of payment gateways, depending
on the business needs (e.g. the client's currency or country etc.)  


#### Tracking categories
Invoices may be assigned custom tags. Tags are grouped under
[custom categories](#tag/trackingcategories) and can help you
better understand your sales performance. The API allows for full
control over the invoice tracking.
tags.name: invoices

tags.description:
A credit note holds information regarding the actual transaction
(such as the client, date, amounts etc.), as well as additional
information needed to render the document as PDF.

#### PDF rendering
The entity responsible for rendering credit notes to PDF is called
[Template](#tag/themes). Templates dictate the design (such as
the layout, color schemes, logo etc) as well as the contents
of the PDF (language, show / hide payment details etc.).

Credit notes may override certain template
settings, to allow for a full control over the PDF rendering of a 
particular credit note. These settings are found under the `template_settings`
group of fields.

#### Client data
Credit notes also keep a copy of all the client information that will
appear on the PDF. As a result you may modify the underlying client
[contact](#tag/contacts) (e.g. update the billing address) 
without affecting the printable form of past transactions with that client.

#### Tracking categories
Credit notes may be assigned custom tags. Tags are grouped under
[custom categories](#tag/trackingcategories) and can help you
better understand your sales performance. The API allows for full
control over the credit note tracking.
tags.name: creditnotes

tags.description:
An estimate holds information regarding the actual offer
(such as the client, date, amounts etc.), as well as additional
information needed to render the document as PDF.

#### PDF rendering
The entity responsible for rendering credit notes to PDF is called
[Template](#tag/themes). Templates dictate the design (such as
the layout, color schemes, logo etc) as well as the contents
of the PDF (language, which columns to show / hide on each line etc.).

Estimates may override certain template
settings, to allow for a full control over the PDF rendering of a 
particular estimate. These settings are found under the `template_settings`
group of fields.

#### Client data
Estimates also keep a copy of all the client information that will
appear on the PDF. As a result you may modify the underlying client
[contact](#tag/contacts) (e.g. update the client address) 
without affecting the printable form of past transactions with that client.

#### Accepted / rejected estimates
Whenever an estimate is sent to the client, they are able to accept or
reject the quote. This information is stored on the `accept_status` field.
The API also allows you to programmatically mark the estimate as 
accepted or rejected, by modifying the `accept_status` field.
tags.name: estimates

tags.description:
Recurring invoices serve as a template, based on which
new invoices are created automatically. The frequency 
that new invoices are generated 
is determined by a corresponding *schedule*.

#### Recurring schedule
The recurring schedule comprises four fields. The `start_datetime`
denotes the first time that a new invoice should be created. The
`interval` and `period` fields specify the frequency 
(e.g. every 2 weeks) and the `end_datetime` the date on which the
last execution will occur. For example, to create a recurring invoice
that will start on Jan 1, 2019 and will generate new invoices
every month until Jan 1, 2020, the recurring schedule would be:

~~~
start_datetime   2019-01-01T10:00:00.0Z
interval         1
period           months
end_datetime     2020-01-01T10:00:00.0Z
~~~

#### Generated invoices
Additional information regarding the generated invoices 
(i.e. the client, invoice lines, appearance settings etc.) is also
stored on the recurring invoice. Therefore, recurring invoices
have most of their fields in common with 
[normal invoices](#tag/invoices). For example, the recurring invoice's
`draft` field controls whether the created invoice will be a draft,
rather than whether the recurring invoice itself is a draft. 
To easily identify the role of each field, please see the field
description in the corresponding endpoints.


#### Tracking categories
Recurring invoices can also hold information about your 
[custom tags](#tag/trackingcategories). Once again, this 
does not categorize the recurring invoice; it dictates
the tags that will be automatically assigned to the created
invoices instead.
tags.name: recurringinvoices

tags.description:
Bills typically represent invoices that you receive from 
suppliers. 

#### Bill lines
Elorus allows you to record every line of the
received invoice separately. If you do not care about the
details, you may choose to store total amounts in a single line.


#### Tracking categories
Bills may be assigned custom tags. Tags are grouped under
[custom categories](#tag/trackingcategories) and can help you
better understand your purchases. The API allows for full
control over the bill tracking.
tags.name: purchases

tags.description:
Supplier credits typically represent credit notes that you receive from 
suppliers. 

#### Supplier credit lines
Elorus allows you to record every line of the
received credit note separately. If you do not care about the
details, you may choose to store total amounts in a single line.


#### Tracking categories
Supplier credits may be assigned custom tags. Tags are grouped under
[custom categories](#tag/trackingcategories) and can help you
better understand your purchases. The API allows for full
control over the supplier credit tracking.
tags.name: purchasecreditnotes

tags.description:
Recurring bills serve as a template, based on which
new bills are created automatically. The frequency 
that new bills are generated 
is determined by a corresponding *schedule*.

#### Recurring schedule
The recurring schedule comprises four fields. The `start_datetime`
denotes the first time that a new bill should be created. The
`interval` and `period` fields specify the frequency 
(e.g. every 2 weeks) and the `end_datetime` the date on which the
last execution will occur. For example, to create a recurring bill
that will start on Jan 1, 2019 and will generate new bills
every month until Jan 1, 2020, the recurring schedule would be:

~~~
start_datetime   2019-01-01T10:00:00.0Z
interval         1
period           months
end_datetime     2020-01-01T10:00:00.0Z
~~~

#### Generated bills
Additional information regarding the generated bills 
(i.e. the supplier, amounts etc.) is also
stored on the recurring bill. Therefore, recurring bills
have most of their fields in common with 
[normal bills](#tag/purchases). For example, 
the recurring bill's
`draft` field controls whether the created bill will be a draft,
rather than whether the recurring bill itself is a draft. 
To easily identify the role of each field, please see the field
description in the corresponding endpoints.


#### Tracking categories
Recurring bills can also hold information about your 
[custom tags](#tag/trackingcategories). Once again, this 
does not categorize the recurring bill; it dictates
the tags that will be automatically assigned to the created
bills instead.
tags.name: recurringpurchases

tags.description:
Stock adjustments enable the direct increase / decrease of a product's stock.
They're used to update the inventory quantity without issuing an 
invoice or bill. Stock adjustments apply only to products / services whose 
[stock is managed](#tag/products).
tags.name: stockadjustments

tags.description:
Payments received represent money that you received in the context
of a single transaction. They can be either a client payment,
a supplier refund or other income (for more information, 
please see the Elorus documentation).


#### IMPORTANT NOTE

>  Historically, a payment record
> could only be associated with a single invoice or supplier credit.
> As of Sep. 2018, Elorus supports associating a single transaction
> with many invoices or supplier credits 
> (e.g. a client pays for multiple invoices at once). 
> However, for backwards compatibility reasons, **this version of the API
> uses the old scheme**. For example, if you use the 
> [payment details endpoint](#operation/cashreceipts_read) of an existing
> client payment, you will get
> the associated invoices in a comma-separated list. However, you may
> create new client payment that is only associated with a single invoice.

#### Tracking categories
Payments received may be assigned custom tags. Tags are grouped under
[custom categories](#tag/trackingcategories) and can help you
better understand your cash flow. The API allows for full
control over the payments received tracking.
tags.name: cashreceipts

tags.description:
Payments received represent money that you sent in the context
of a single transaction. They can be either a supplier payment,
a client refund or other expenses (for more information, 
please see the Elorus documentation).


#### IMPORTANT NOTE

>  Historically, a payment record
> could only be associated with a single bill or credit note.
> As of Sep. 2018, Elorus supports associating a single transaction
> with many bills or credit notes 
> (e.g. a you pay off multiple supplier invoices at once). 
> However, for backwards compatibility reasons, **this version of the API
> uses the old scheme**. For example, if you use the 
> [payment details endpoint](#operation/cashpayments_read) of an existing
> supplier payment, you will get
> the associated bills in a comma-separated list. However, you may
> create new supplier payment that is only associated with a single bill.

#### Tracking categories
Payments sent may be assigned custom tags. Tags are grouped under
[custom categories](#tag/trackingcategories) and can help you
better understand your cash flow. The API allows for full
control over the payments sent tracking.
tags.name: cashpayments

tags.description:
Recurring payments received serve as a template, based on which
new payment received records are created automatically. The frequency 
that new payments are generated is determined by a corresponding *schedule*.

#### Recurring schedule
The recurring schedule comprises four fields. The `start_datetime`
denotes the first time that a new record should be created. The
`interval` and `period` fields specify the frequency 
(e.g. every 2 weeks) and the `end_datetime` the date on which the
last execution will occur. For example, to create a recurring payment received
that will start on Jan 1, 2019 and will generate new payment records
every month until Jan 1, 2020, the recurring schedule would be:

~~~
start_datetime   2019-01-01T10:00:00.0Z
interval         1
period           months
end_datetime     2020-01-01T10:00:00.0Z
~~~

#### Generated records
[Payments received](#tag/cashreceipts) records may be of the 
following types: Client payments, supplier refunds or 
other income. However, recurring payments received 
**may only create records of type *other income* **. 


#### Tracking categories
Recurring payments received can also hold information about your 
[custom tags](#tag/trackingcategories). This data 
does not refer to the recurring payment itself; it dictates
the tags that will be automatically assigned to the created
records instead.
tags.name: recurringcashreceipts

tags.description:
To use these endpoints, *cheque management* must be enabled for
the organization in question.
tags.name: incomingcheques

tags.description:
To use these endpoints, *cheque management* must be enabled for
the organization in question.
tags.name: outgoingcheques

tags.description:
This entity represents inventory items that 
your company may sell or purchase. Products / services may be
assigned to invoices, credit notes etc. and are primarily 
used to:

- View sales / purchase reports per item
- Manage inventory stock


#### Products / services in sales & purchases

In real world, products may be sold, purchased or both. 
In Elorus, you must explicitly specify whether you buy or 
sell a product: 

To be able to associate a product with an invoice or 
credit note, the product's
`sales` property must be set to `true`. 
To be able to associate a product with a bill or 
a supplier credit, the product's
`purchases` property must be set to `true`  


#### Stock management

To let keep track of the product's stock in your inventory, 
the `manage` property must be set to `true`. 
Each time the product is being sold 
(i.e. an invoice line is associated with the product) 
the stock will increase as dictated by the quantity. Each time
the product is being purchased (i.e. associated with a bill)
the stock will decrease as dictated by the quantity.

#### Tracking categories
Products / services may be assigned custom tags. Tags are grouped under
[custom categories](#tag/trackingcategories) and are primarily a reporting
tool: they can help you better understand your sales / purchases.
tags.name: products

tags.description:
You may retrieve the list of payment gateways via the API. However,
to update or create new records, the web application must be used.
tags.name: paymentgateways

tags.description:
Reminders may be sent to both clients & teammates whenever an important
event occurs. 

Each reminder serves a different purpose. You may automatically 
notify your clients whenever their amount due surpasses a fixed 
limit, or whenever a specific invoice is overdue more than X 
days, etc. The `application`, `type` and `options` fields 
work together to control the reminder's behavior.'
tags.name: reminders

tags.description:
Tracking categories are primarily a reporting tool to help you
monitor the performance of all sorts of records. Think of each category
as a group of conceptually related, mutually exclusive options (tags) that
can be used to identify a record.

For example, to monitor your sales by continent, you may create a
tracking category named "Continent". The available options will be
"North America", "South America", "Europe", "Asia", "Africa", 
"Australia" and "Antarctica". Once the category is created, 
you may associate each invoice with exactly one continent.

Tracking categories can be used as filters in reports (e.g. you can filter
the results by continent), or even as groupers (e.g. you may view
your revenues per continent and calculate sub-totals).
tags.name: trackingcategories

tags.description:
Templates dictate the way that invoices, estimates, credit notes etc. will
be rendered. They hold information about the content (e.g. which columns 
to show on the line items table, whether to display the outstanding amount 
or not, etc.) and the design (e.g. colors, fonts, static texts). 
Templates may also be used to specify default messages that will
be used when communicating with your clients via email.

#### IMPORTANT NOTE

> Templates have been the subject of a major update, where new functionality
> was added and some features were removed / deprecated. The update took place
> after API v1.0 was released. The following endpoints
> are generally forwards-compatible, however you should avoid performing 
> actions that modify templates (i.e. `POST`, `PUT` & `PATCH` operations), 
> unless it's really necessary.

Each template is associated with a language. You may use multiple templates
to address international clients and issue invoices in different languages.
tags.name: themes

tags.description:
Document types define distinct kinds of documents, each following a separate
numbering sequence. The most common document type is the "Invoice". If, 
for example, one needs to issue "Tax invoices" and "Retail invoices" 
separately, they would create two new document types.

Each document type applies to a specific type of records. You may create 
document types that apply to invoices, credit notes or estimates.

Finally, document types specify the translations to use when invoicing
in multiple languages.
tags.name: documenttypes

tags.description:
Numbering sequences are prefixes that define a new, unique numbering for
invoices, credit notes or estimates. For example, given an
invoicing sequence "A" and a second sequence "B", your invoices may look
like:
- Invoice A-1
- Invoice A-2
- Invoice A-3
- Invoice B-1
- Invoice B-2
- ...

Sequences are always associated with a [document type](#tag/documenttypes),
which in turn applies to either invoices, credit notes, recurring invoices
or estimates. Using the sales numbering sequences endpoints, you may only 
access sequences associated with invoices, credit notes and 
recurring invoices.
tags.name: salesseries

tags.description:
Numbering sequences are prefixes that define a new, unique numbering for
estimates, invoices or credit notes. For example, given an
invoicing sequence "A" and a second sequence "B", your estimates may look
like:
- Estimate A-1
- Estimate A-2
- Estimate A-3
- Estimate B-1
- Estimate B-2
- ...

Sequences are always associated with a [document type](#tag/documenttypes),
which in turn applies to either invoices, credit notes, recurring invoices
or estimates. Using the estimates numbering sequences endpoints, you may only 
access sequences associated with estimates.
tags.name: estimateseries

tags.description: Roles describe a set of predefined permissions that allow or deny access to specific functionality. Each organization user is always assigned to a role, so that Elorus knows how to handle permissions. There are two types of roles: **Core roles** and **custom roles**. **Core roles** come pre-installed on every organization and cannot by modified or deleted. Currently, there are three core roles: - **Administrators**, that can perform **any** action, including organization management (manage users, subscription plan, company settings). Every organization must always have at least one administrator. - **Business manager** members, that can perform any action, **except from** organization management (cannot manage users, subscription plan or company settings). - **Financial advisors**, that can only view financial data, are not allowed to edit or create records, cannot manage the organization users or settings and have no access to the time tracking functionality. - **Employees**, that can **only track time** for projects they're a member of. They do not have access to financial data and are not allowed to manage projects under any circumstances. - **Project managers**, that can track time for projects they're a member of. They **may be allowed** to manage projects & other people's time on a per-project basis. They have access **only** to the financial data of projects they manage. On the other hand, **custom roles** can be created by the organization administrators and explicitly specify whether users should be allowed or denied access to each and every functionality, to suit all business needs. Using this version of the api you may retrieve the list of custom roles, along with their ids and descriptions, so that you may easily identify the role when using the [organization users](#tag/users) API endpoints.
tags.name: organizationroles
